assertions.title: convey the unordered list role
assertions.rationale: A screen reader user needs to know that content is contained in an unordered list.
examples: Typically, the word "list" is announced when entering the list, then the word "bullet" is announced when entering a list item. Together, these two pieces of information convey the unordered list role.

assertions.title: convey the list boundaries
assertions.rationale: A screen reader user needs to know when they enter and exit a list.
examples: In reading mode, there might be a stop for both the start end end of the list. When entering the list, something like "list of x items" is announced. When leaving the list, something like "end of list" is announced.

In reading mode, there might not be a stop for the start or end of the list. In this case, the screen reader might announce the first item as something like 1 of x, and the last item as x of x, or otherwise announce the boundaries when entering or exiting the list.

In interaction mode, there will not be a stop for the start or end of the list. In this case, the screen reader might announce the first item as something like "list of x items", and the last item as "x of x", or "end of list", or otherwise announce the the boundaries when entering or exiting the list.

assertions.title: convey the number of items in the list
assertions.rationale: A screen reader user needs know how many items are in the list.
A screen reader user might find it helpful to know what nesting level they are at.
examples: A screen reader might announce something like "nesting level x" when entering a nested list
